header_summary:
Yuval Kogman introduces a complex discussion on the need for nuanced evaluation systems within technical communities, particularly emphasizing the challenges in merging technical merit and community support into a singular voting framework. Kogman proposes a model allowing for independent assessments of technical value and community sentiment, advocating for a more flexible and expressive system to reduce misunderstandings and foster inclusivity. This approach, coupled with a critique of current methods using a color scheme, aims to better capture the multifaceted nature of developer opinions and community dynamics, drawing an analogy with the Keynesian beauty contest to highlight the speculative nature of evaluating proposals ([Keynesian beauty contest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keynesian_beauty_contest)).

Ava Chow announces the availability of Bitcoin Core version v28.1rc1 release candidate binaries, inviting the community to participate in testing to ensure the new version's stability and reliability. This step is crucial for identifying any remaining issues before the final release, with the binaries and source code accessible for review and compilation. The process, including downloading binaries from [Bitcoin Core's official website](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-28.1/test.rc1/) and accessing release notes on [GitHub](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/v28.1rc1/doc/release-notes.md), emphasizes community engagement in refining and enhancing the Bitcoin Core software.

Antoine Riard delves into the security challenges facing Bitcoin, specifically addressing a transaction-relay jamming attack that threatens time-sensitive contracting protocols like lightning channels. The report outlines the technical mechanisms of the attack, its impact on the network, and potential mitigation strategies, urging further investigation and experimentation to safeguard decentralized financial networks from such sophisticated adversarial tactics. Riard's analysis, documented meticulously from initial findings to public disclosure, serves as a foundation for ongoing discussions on enhancing network resilience ([transaction-relay jamming attack details](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CALZpt+EptER=p+P7VN3QAb9n=dODA9_LnR9xZwWpRsdAwedv=w@mail.gmail.com/T/#u#m4fcd81d3fbf25a2571b51eba2221cea7238279cd)).

In the discourse on cryptocurrency's role as cash, "securitybrahh" explores the skepticism towards Monero and Bitcoin's fungibility, suggesting a preference for Monero due to its privacy features. The discussion highlights the ongoing debates within the cryptocurrency community regarding the best approaches to achieve scalability, privacy, and functionality improvements. This includes technical considerations like the CTV soft fork and transaction pools through OP_CAT, aiming to enhance Bitcoin's utility and address concerns about its role and fungibility as digital cash ([further reading on fungibility](https://sethforprivacy.com/posts/fungibility-graveyard/)).

recent_posts.title: op_CAT vs op_CTV vs XMR
recent_posts.summary:
- Skepticism exists towards Monero and Bitcoin as fulfilling the cash role, with a gap identified.
- Monero is preferred for its stable value and fungibility, concerns loom over Bitcoin's changes.
- Technical advancements like CTV and OP_CAT could enhance Bitcoin, while Monero emphasizes privacy.

active_posts.title: Covenants Support - Bitcoin Wiki
active_posts.summary:
- A new initiative solicits Bitcoin developers' opinions on covenant proposals via a wiki draft.
- It aims to facilitate consensus for soft forks, similar to the SegWit support page approach.
- Developers can contribute by adding opcodes and insights, enhancing proposals like OP_CTV.

active_posts.title: Full Disclosure: "Transaction-Relay Throughput Overflow Attacks against Off-Chain Protocols"
active_posts.summary:
- The report analyzes a new attack on bitcoin, specifically lightning channels, via transaction jamming.
- It details two attack variants, "high overflow" and "low overflow," affecting transaction propagation.
- Proposed mitigation strategies focus on resilience for lightning nodes and require base-layer intervention.

active_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.1 Release Candidate 1 Available
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v28.1rc1 release candidate binaries are now available for testing.
- The source code and preliminary release notes are accessible on GitHub for review.
- This release aims to identify and fix any issues before the final version v28.1 launch.

active_posts.title: Libbitcoin for Core people
active_posts.summary:
- Eric Voskuil shows Libbitcoin's IBD is up to 15 times faster than Bitcoin Core with `-assumevalid`.
- Libbitcoin uses an event-based, asynchronous system with a relational database for better performance.
- Despite its efficiency, Libbitcoin has not fully addressed DoS protection or implemented pruning.

active_posts.title: Unspendable keys in descriptors
active_posts.summary:
- Miniscript integration with taproot enables new wallet development possibilities.
- Several methods to create unspendable keys have trade-offs, including issues with fingerprinting.
- The root xpub with a random chaincode is most practical for hardware signers currently.

active_posts.title: Radpool: Decentralised Mining Pool With Futures Contracts For Payouts
active_posts.summary:
- Radpool aims to decentralize mining with a syndicate of Mining Service Providers (MSPs).
- It introduces a payout mechanism using Discreet Log Contracts for miner compensation.
- The initiative encourages decentralization, reducing variance for miners and increasing MSP yields.

today_in_history_posts.title: Schnorr and taproot (etc) upgrade
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The article outlines four potential improvements to Bitcoin's system, including new segwit versions and opcodes.
- It proposes changes like 33-byte v1 witness addresses for enhanced transaction verification methods.
- The author considers these changes modest and discusses the possibility of independent OP_SUCCESS upgrades.

today_in_history_posts.title: [META] Organization of 1.1 Spec Effort
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Matt Corallo prefers IRC meetings over regular calls for Lightning updates.
- He argues critical discussions should occur on GitHub or mailing lists, not live meetings.
- Peter Todd agrees, highlighting textual communication is more accessible for many.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's scalability involves creating 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks" for broader user transactions.
- These banks range from federated sidechains to solutions not relying on third parties, like coinpools.
- Addressing scalability requires a balance of security and affordability, with innovation in Layer 2 protocols and concern for Bitcoin's original vision.
